verses.text: Be merciful to me, O LORD, for I am in distress; my eyes grow weak with sorrow, my soul and my body with grief.
My life is consumed by anguish and my years by groaning; my strength fails because of my affliction, and my bones grow weak.
Because of all my enemies, I am the utter contempt of my neighbors; I am a dread to my friends- those who see me on the street flee from me.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 31:10
rsbNotes.text: 31:10 iniquity. Several ancient translations read, “affliction,” which draws support from the psalm’s general theme of distress from outside forces rather than from the psalmist’s guilt.

verses.text: I am forgotten by them as though I were dead; I have become like broken pottery.
For I hear the slander of many; there is terror on every side; they conspire against me and plot to take my life.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 31:12
rsbNotes.text: 31:12 broken vessel. A metaphor for serious illness, even death (Eccl. 12:6).

verses.text: But I trust in you, O LORD; I say, "You are my God."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 31:14
rsbNotes.text: 31:14 You are my God. A simple and foundational confession that David is in covenant with God.

verses.text: My times are in your hands; deliver me from my enemies and from those who pursue me.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 31:15
rsbNotes.text: 31:15 My times. The psalmist knows that God controls history in general and his life in particular. This comforts him in his distress.

verses.text: Let your face shine on your servant; save me in your unfailing love.
Let me not be put to shame, O LORD, for I have cried out to you; but let the wicked be put to shame and lie silent in the grave.
Let their lying lips be silenced, for with pride and contempt they speak arrogantly against the righteous.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 31:16
rsbNotes.text: 31:16 face shine. See the priestly blessing of Num. 6:25. The metaphor of God’s face represents His loving presence that will bring salvation to the psalmist.
